title: Georgia House - Day 30 (2026-03-17)
summary:
Here is a structured markdown summary of the Georgia House - Day 30 (2026-03-17) session:

## Overview
The session featured a notable speech by a visiting pastor, who shared an encouraging story from the Bible and reflected on the work of the legislators. No major bills were passed, but the transcript suggests a thoughtful and reflective tone to the proceedings.

## Key Actions
None.

## Bills Introduced (First Reading)
None noted.

## Notable Moments
- A visiting pastor gave a speech, sharing an encouraging story from the Bible and reflecting on the work of the legislators.
- The pastor discussed the obstacles and problem-solving process the characters faced in the biblical story, drawing parallels to the legislators' work.
- The pastor acknowledged the obscure aspects of the biblical story and encouraged the legislators to use their imagination to fully envision the scene.

## Votes
None recorded.

## Attendance
No explicit notes on quorum.

## Adjournment
The transcript does not include details on the adjournment or the date of the next session.
transcript:
you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you you I appreciate that introduction. Although I'm concerned since I've come here, everybody I've met has sounded incredulous when they've said, your nose pasture as if that's an unusual and unexpected thing. So we'll talk a little later. I wouldn't be able to cover that one. Mr. Speaker, I thank you for having me here. Members, I appreciate the invitation and the opportunity. And I want to thank you for the work and the service that you do. One of the things that's been fun here this morning.

hearing about the way the schedule sets up and the various committee meetings. And my hunch is, because I know as a Georgia citizen and a voter, we don't have a clue what you do most all day long, right? And I empathize. I'm a pastor. I've been a pastor for 28 years. And in my 28 years, I've heard the same joke every day. And it goes something like this. What do you do the rest of the week? Just be quiet a job, working one day a week for about an hour. And I always say when you have that opinion, that's why I preach long time. I'm giving you your money's worth. But I'm not going to do that today. What I'd like to do in this time is bring you some encouragement and bring you a way of saying thank you for all that you do. What I'd like to do today is share a story with you, a story from the Scriptures. I am fond of stories and storytelling. I was blessed to grow up in a family of storytellers. One of the things about the Scriptures when you find it is that Jesus loved to tell stories. And they get us in it. The reason He tells stories is because they help us see ourselves in the story. So as I share this with you today, I'm going to invite you to use your imagination. I'm going to invite you to put yourself in the seat in that place. I know it was a long time ago. It was an ancient setting. It's their sum familiarity. And forgive me, I'll also give them to understand Uncle Dom that it may not be as far back for you as for others. But somebody asked me to share that along the way. So if you have any questions about the veracity of the story, you know who to ask in that one. Allow me to share with you a story. It comes from the Gospel of Mark in the New Testament. It's in chapter two. And I'm not going to read it to you verbatim. I'm going to pull some sections. I'd like to share this as a story. Most of you, and many of you have probably already heard it. But one of the things about those stories is I like to get into them and understand them a little better. And I hope that you'll find the encouragement I spoke about in this. In the story, we're told that Jesus is in the little town of Capernum, which is on the north shore of the Sea of Galilee. A few years ago, I had the opportunity to go to Capernum and to walk through the ruins. And if you've ever been there, the streets are incredibly small. The houses are very small. And we're told in the story that there are so many people packed in. Jesus is preaching from a house, probably standing in the doorway. And there's just no way to get any closer. Those narrow streets are full of people. And they're listening to the story. And you kind of have that image in your head. And then the next part we're told in the story is a long comes a group of folks who are bringing their friend to Jesus. He's paralyzed. He can do nothing for himself, but his friends. And as at least four of them, because we're told they're carrying the corners of his mat, but there may have been more. And they're coming to bring him to Jesus. They've decided we're going to take care of, we'll call him Bubba to give him a name. We're going to take care of Bubba. We're going to bring him in. And Jesus is going to see you. And so they come in. But the crowd is there. There's this obstacle. There's no way through that large bunch that's there. Now I know the members in this body are familiar with running into obstacles. You know what it is to have a plan and a goal. And suddenly something gets in the way and it doesn't work. And one of the things the wording of the scripture doesn't tell us, but if you've ever had any experience with human beings, you know this happened. They looked at the mess. They looked at the crowd. They knew what they wanted to do. And there's that one person in the group. I'm certain he said, well, it'll never work. Eure exists in every group somewhere, right? And that was, this is never going to happen. My soul just go home. It won't work. You had that other person in the group. I don't know who it was, but there's that person who is sure optimism with no practical application. You know, that was the person saying, we can do this. I have no idea how, but we can do this. And then you had that other person in the group. I'm absolutely certain whose skill is pointing out how everybody else's idea is wrong. They have no idea of their own, but everybody else's idea is wrong. And you can put in anybody in that. If you've been with a group of people, you know this to be true. If you find four people trying to make a decision as to where to go to lunch, then you know what happened here, right? And so somewhere, somebody, maybe it was a group decision, maybe there was that out of the box thinker, we don't know. There was the one that said, I know what we'll do. We'll go up on the roof. We'll go from above. And so evidently probably went around behind the house, climbed up onto the roof. And this is where, if, forgive me, to say it this way, the Bible annoys me. Because it says things so briefly, so lachonically, that if you don't stop and think about it, you don't realize the extent of what's happening. You're told they got up on the roof. Remember they've got a friend on a mat. And somehow they get him up onto the roof of this house. And then as you get down into the passage, in verse 5, you have this very easy passage. And it says, and they lifted up the roof above Jesus and dug through it. Now stop there for just a second. It's where I need your imagination to come with me some. Stop there. Because in the ancient world, you didn't spend time in your house. It was dark, it was small, it was cramped. As a matter of fact, like the old Drifter song, you went up on the roof, where the air was fresh and sweet. That was the best place to be. And so those roofs were solid constructions. They were usually interlocked timbers with dirt packed in tightly enough to be like concrete. By the way, Nol didn't tell you I'm an ex history teacher, so this could go a while. So just brace yourselves there. But they packed in the dirt on the... They packed in the dirt on those roofs and had these solid roofs. So there is no way that they just lifted the roof. It took some work to get in there. Now, here's where I need you to really come with me. To get into that roof and it says in the scripture, they dug through it. And we're not talking just a little scratching. I don't know if they had pickaxes with them. I don't know what they had, but it would have had to be some serious work. And you can't tell me those folks on a one story building above Jesus digging into the roof don't draw the attention of the crowd. I've seen whole congregations lose with a complete train of thought when a wasp, blew across the congregation. And everybody went, you know. So you know folks were watching the crowd up there on the roof. You know they were intently watching it. And this point nobody's listening to Jesus. It sounds blasphemous, but I am certain of it because that's what people do. They're all watching. And you know there's somebody out there going, y'all need to stop. Y'all go get in trouble. Do you know who owns this house? You better not dig into the roof of that house. And I imagine there's groups among the group that's up there digging. There's somebody going, y'all, maybe this wasn't a good idea. I imagine Bubba on his mat is thinking, I'm just going to get in trouble. Y'all just take me home. We'll try this another time. I don't want to be a part of whatever trouble is coming because of this. But they don't. They keep digging. And by this point, the other thing you have to picture is Jesus inside the building. He's not oblivious. If you can't take a pickaxe to the roof and not know somebody's up there. And they're hacking away. I imagine there's dirt coming down through the ceiling, drifting down on top of them. I imagine at this point in Jesus' stock, how do you go on? There's a point where you're interrupted and you can't go. My first church I served down in Chester, Georgia. I will never forget. I was preaching my sermon and my three-year-old son was on the back row. And he stood up and walker in his three-year-old voice said, Daddy, stop talking. I'm hungry. It would have been bad enough if there wasn't a chorus of amends that followed. So it kind of ended that service. And so I imagine in that pandemonium there's a stop. And I'd like to picture Jesus look it up. And they're heading to come that moment. Again, go a little further here. Heading to come that moment where they got a hole about maybe yay big in the roof. And somebody's face stuck in there and went, I can see him. We're almost there. Keep going. Because we're told they opened it up big enough to lower their friend in. This didn't happen in three minutes or two minutes. This was a massive effort. So they finally get the roof all the way open and they lower him down. And at this point, you know everybody got quiet. What's Jesus going to do? What are they going to say? What's going to happen at this point? And this is where I get a little frustrated. Sometimes the Bible as well. Because I want stage directions. Tell me what Jesus, what was the expression on his face? What did the crowd do? We don't get that. We're just told they opened it up and lowered him down. I imagine Jesus. And this is just me. I imagine a huge smile on his face. And I tell you why. How could you not look up through that hole at these crazy hair brain group that just dug through the roof? And they're all standing up. They're sweating and they're dirty and they're filthy and they're expectant and they're hopeful and they're grinning. And he looks up at them and he looks down at the friend that's on the floor. And you know somebody out in the crowd is going, they're going to get it now. And they did. He looks down at the man on the mat and looks up at them. And it says this in the scripture. This is to me one of the best parts of the whole story. This is at chapter 5 of Mark 2. When Jesus saw their faith, he said to the man, your sins are forgiven. Now there's a whole theological discussion about forgiving of sins and that sort of thing. We're not going to, that's not this time and place. And Jesus does go on to heal him. But I want to grab that passage when he saw their faith. As you remember the paralyzed man, he has no agency whatsoever. Like I said, he's probably going guys, let's just go home. But they brought him. They've lowered Baba down. He's there in front of Jesus and it's going to happen. And Jesus is looking up at those folks on the roof. And that's what I want you to grab today. He's looking up at folks who were determined. He's looking up at folks that overcame obstacles. He's looking up at folks who love their friend, who understood the need and did what whatever it took in the face of criticism, in the face of disagreements, in the face of anger, whatever happened in the face of a hard roof and a dull pickaxe. I don't know what all went on, but it was worth it to them to do so. And I think Jesus smiled for this reason because they were people after his own heart. For Jesus himself would later go on and show what leadership was all about when he took off his robe and washed his disciples' feet. Jesus would go on and show that leadership is like those folks on that roof. It's about sacrifice. It's about giving up of yourself for someone else, something that he would live out all the way to that cross. This is why I wanted to share that with you today. Every one of us runs into obstacles. And this body, probably more than most, has to deal with those things. And I want to thank you for that, not because I want you to struggle, but because I appreciate the sacrifice you make. And it may be that a lot of folks never see it, and it may be that a lot of folks never understand it. But the truth is, those folks who think outside the box, who manage to come together, because see, there wasn't one person carrying that mat. They couldn't be carried by one, two, or three, had to be at least four. It had to be a group. They had to come together, and there's no other way to make it work. And I thank you for making it work. I thank you for being willing to wrestle and being willing to struggle and listening to those around you and doing what needs to be done for the sake of folks who may not ever truly understand the work that went into it. And so I want to say thank you. And I hope you'll take that passage in the story today as an encouragement. You see, I think we're all called at some level at some time, at some point, to be a member of what I call the hole in the roof gang, those folks that stand up and dig the hole and bring their friends to where they're needed. And step out. Thank you for being that. Thank you for serving in that way. And thank you for all that you do. Today we pray. Almighty God, we come before you this day and thank you for the blessings that you have given us in such abundance. Blessings of bounteous resources and limitless potential. We thank you for the beauty and strength of our state and most of all we thank you for the wonderful people here who make it such a vibrant and special place. And we thank you for the holy privilege of serving them. Make that we would approach the tasks and challenges before us with your graciousness. Help us to see and appreciate one another through your eyes. Give us we pray the ability to will the best in all situations. Offer strength where needed. Flexibility and creativity in the face of challenge and encouragement in all things. May your wisdom be in our deliberations. May your creator's hand be in all we're tasked to do. And may your perfect love be in every word and thought. Use things we pray in your precious and gracious presence and in whom we put our trust. Amen. Would you join me in the Pledge of Allegiance? I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America and to the Republic for which it stands. One nation under God, indivisible with liberty and justice for all. More keepers will unlock the doors. Members may greet the chaplain in the south any room. Chair recognizes chairman Hogan, the chair of the committee on information and audits. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Your committee on information and audits has read the journal of the previous legislative day and found it to be correct. And furthermore, Mr. Speaker, happy St. Pat's Day. And I've been to Ireland several times and I've never seen a snake over there. And each had the honor of getting all the snakes off of Ireland, supposedly. May the road rise to meet you, the great Irish blessing. And may the wind be always at your back. May the sun shine warm upon your face and the rain has fall soft upon your fields. And until we meet again, may God hold you in the palm of his hand. And a happy St. Patrix Day to you, Mr. Chairman. Sometimes I think I know where they brought the snakes though. here recognizes representative Roger Bruce see down here okay we'll come back to him representative Bennett is recognized for a morning order good morning Mr. Speaker and colleagues thank you and happy St. Patrick's Day to each of you on your desk you have a newsletter that is in starts with healthy choices and what is food equity when I made a report a couple of weeks ago I had one of our colleagues to walk up to me to tell me that he did not know about food deserts or food equity so I have provided this information and I just like to share just a bit with you food insecurity at least the food deserts in Georgia USDA defines food insecurity as a household level economic and social condition of limited and uncertain access to adequate food fresh fruits vegetables and fresh meats mix mix a difference in our health care Georgia currently ranks at the bottom quadrant in our health rankings compared to other states and so having access to food healthy foods in our community will help improve our health rankings so thank you Georgia for providing our farmers with an opportunity to bring foods to this to the urban and rural areas so we can improve our health rankings thank you chair recognizes representative Tyler Paul Smith for a morning order thank you miss speaker good morning ladies and gentlemen this house I rise today to recognize a very special guest we have among us today this young man tends my own beloved alma mater a gentleman in a scholar already majoring in mechanical engineering with a minor in Chinese achieved a great point average his first semester of 3.823 earning gold stars he displays on the collar of his uniform as citadel near as it's a hundred and eighty th birthday this come Sunday I'm hopeful and encouraged by young men such as Lauren Wiley everything a citadel cadet should be cadet I'm proud of you and everything you will become please help

me and welcoming Lauren Wiley Mcdonald the fourth to this house. Chair recognizes representative Holly Laura Morning Order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Hello colleagues. As you know, March is women's history month. And so it is probably best for us at this time where most of our teachers and even their students don't really see us as a unified body when they watch the news. But fortunately for so many of us, we know that we have women teachers who have poured into us. In Georgia, we have 826,000 women teachers in our public schools, our private charter schools, all the way from vocational, as well as even in the college sphere. So we just thank you. If we can't at this time, let's show them how much we love them. If you have a positive women teacher who has been able to help you out in your life, please let's rise to our feet and give them a hand clap of praise. Thank you. Are you the well? Chair recognizes representative Roger Bruce for a Morning Order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Quite often, you know, we come to the well to announce that somebody has left the planet. I come this morning to announce that we got a new person on the planet. I am so proud to announce that I have my first granddaughter. Nova, Marley Bruce is in the world. Thank you very much. Chair recognizes representative Jasmine Clark for a Morning Order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Let's talk about trains. Trains are absolutely essential to our economy. They transport our goods from point A to point B, so that those goods are available to all of us. I truly appreciate the value that our trains provide to all of us. However, I believe it is absolutely essential that when these trains are doing their business, that they work collaboratively with the communities that they travel within. Blocked railroad crossings due to stopped trains or train maintenance can cause significant disruption to communities and potential public safety hazards for emergency vehicles. However, communities have very little recourse to address these disruptions because trains are federally regulated and a federal railroad administration has no specific regulations regarding blocked crossings. I would like to urge the FRA to do more and I invite you to sign on to HR 1023 and urging resolution to ask the FRA to do more to stop blocked crossings in our communities. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Chair recognizes representative Rebecca Mitchell for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I usually come up here with slightly heavier morning orders, but I have a delightful one this morning. I don't know how many people in this house have been here for the majority of their birthdays, but there is an eight-year-old right outside today who has been here for the majority of his. So if you have a moment to walk outside and say happy birthday to Zander, he would love to talk to you. And he would like you to know that he really loves seeing his own family reflected in the books in his school library. Thank you very much and I yield the well. Chair recognizes representative Wade for a morning order. Good morning colleagues. I rise to celebrate the Lumpkin County Women's Basketball team for being the triple A basketball champs for the state of Georgia. It's their first state championship. And one of the most special things about this team is they have been playing together as a team for a long time.
